critique: This document is a waiver under the Trade Act of 1974 with respect to the People's Republic of China. It involves international trade relations and does not directly address social or domestic issues. Therefore, many of the axes will be neutral. The waiver itself doesn't inherently expand executive power, but the act of waiving provisions could be seen as a slight expansion depending on the context of the original act. The document does not directly relate to immigration, federalism, national security vs. civil liberties, economic regulation, or social inclusion.
